bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 22, 1941

div1.p: Hench argues that Ames would be a good choice to include in the yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 22, 1941
div1.opener:
Mr. Kellogg Please return to
J. R. Kean when you have no
further use for this & Gen
Trubys letter
JRK
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
August 22, 1941
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am glad to have your suggestions that if the Wyeth people are willing,
the name of either Folk or Hanberry should be given to the soldier behind Moran
in the group on the right. I am glad you corrected me. I meant of course the
Spanish immigrants, not the Cuban volunteers and I gather that you do not think
the one Spanish immigrant in the picture should be named but should be nameless
and represent the group. I note your comments against specifically naming Carter
or Ames in the group, but this still leaves unfinished the matter of naming the
second man on the upper right (the one sitting on the porch rail). Kellogg tells
me that Dr. Cooke is the other of these two men, that is, the officer with the
white uniform. The other unnamed person will have to be an officer as he has an
officer's insignia on and Cornwell definitely separated the privates from the
officers. Must we leave this man unnamed? Since this picture will, as time
passes, assume more and more historical significance, it seems a shame to have
an anonymous figure therein. I agree that the inclusion of Carter would be a
considerable stretch of the imagination. It was my thought that Dr. Ames might
be included as a recognition of his obviously excellent care of those who came
down with experimental yellow fever and also because he was officially in imme-
diate charge of Camp Lazear or at least Reed says so on the top of page 71, Senate
Document. (However, Moran disputes this, saying he never saw Ames at Camp Lazear
while he was there.) He, I should believe, belongs in the group as much as Gen-
eral Truby who was inserted as a matter of convenience and courtesy because he
was at least temporary commanding officer in the hospital, because he found
Lazear's important notebook and because he has been so helpful all along.

If you do not agree that Ames' name should be attached to the figure be-
side Dr. Cooke, can you suggest some other officer? Unfortunately, according to
the telephone conversation which I had with Kellogg a few days ago, he must have
this information on Monday. Would it be possible for you to write to him directly,
sending me a carbon copy of your letter by writing in pencil and using the enclosed
carbon paper? You remember Mr. Kellogg's address is 257 Cornelison Avenue, Jersey
City, N. J. I enclose an airmail special delivery for your reply to me. Do you
think Dr. Pinto, having received a negative inoculation, deserves to be in more
than Dr. Ames?

I realize that I have scandalously neglected General Truby. I have been
so very busy that my yellow fever researches have been neglected. I intend to
write him very shortly, telling him many things that I have not been able to tell
him yet. Rather than being disturbed by his frank comments on the Hemmeter photo-
stats, I was completely delighted. He seems to be a wonderful gentleman and I hope
to visit him on my vacation in California next February. In fact, I am choosing
General Kean - 2- August 22, 1941
a California vacation specifically to meet him and Mrs. Lazear.

Thank you so much for your comments on the Bullard article. I still
have more information to send you which I will do when I have more time. Please
keep the list of the data I found in the National Archives.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Philip S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
psh:ds
P. S. Since dictating this this morning, I have just received the
enclosed letter from General Truby. He favors naming Ames. Note that the figure
we are naming has an officer's coat, apparently with a lieutenant's insignia. I
believe Ames was a contract surgeon with a rank of acting assistant surgeon.
Would the uniform portrayed be contradictory to Ames' position? The uniform of
the figure we are naming does not seem to differ materially from that of Lazear
who was also a contract surgeon. It is of course too late to redo the face after
a photograph of Ames but I don't suppose his family would worry too much over
that if he had the honor of being named.
P.S.H.
